title: How to Format the C Drive With Windows 7: Quick Tutorial

steps.title: Back up and save your files.
steps.content: Back up and save your files. Formatting the C drive will erase all files, programs, and information saved on the C drive, so you may want to back up any files you want saved. Save your files to an external hard drive or disc, or save your files to another folder on the network, if applicable.

steps.title: Obtain your computer name if connected to a network.
steps.content: Obtain your computer name if connected to a network. After your C drive has been formatted, you may be prompted for your computer name during the installation process in order to reconnect to the network. Go to your computer's "Start" menu, right-click on "Computer," then select "Properties" from the menu that appears. Your computer name will be shown below "Computer name, domain, and workgroup settings."

steps.title: Insert the Windows 7 installation disc.
steps.content: Insert the Windows 7 installation disc. In some cases, you may have the Windows 7 installation program saved on a Universal Serial Bus (USB) flash drive, which can also be inserted.

steps.title: Turn off your computer.
steps.content: Turn off your computer. Your computer will have to reboot in order to read the Windows 7 installation disc. Open your "Start" menu, then click on "Shut Down."

steps.title: Power on your computer.
steps.content: Power on your computer. When your computer powers back on, it will read the installation disc and begin the formatting process. Click the "Install Now" option.

steps.title: Format your C drive.
steps.content: Format your C drive. After the computer has recognized the installation disc, you will be prompted to press any key on your keyboard to continue. The installation wizard will then appear on your screen. Select your language from the "Install Windows" page, then click on "Next" to proceed. Read and review the Windows 7 license terms. In order to proceed to the next screen, you will be required to place a check mark in the box next to "I accept the license terms." Select "Custom" when prompted to indicated the type of installation you want to perform. Select "Drive options (advanced)" when asked where you want Windows installed. Choosing this option will allow you to select the C drive as the only drive you want to format. Click on your "C" disk drive when Windows asks which partition you want to "change," or install. Your computer will then begin formatting, or erasing, all the data currently existing on your C drive. Windows will notify you when the formatting procedure has finished.

steps.title: Re-install Windows 7 on your C drive.
steps.content: Re-install Windows 7 on your C drive. After your C drive has been formatted, you will be required to re-install Windows 7 to that partition. Click on "Next" after Windows has notified you that the formatting procedure has completed. The Windows installation wizard will continue to walk you through the installation process. You will be prompted for your computer name if you are connected to a network, and for information such as your user name.

steps.title: Restore your saved files.
steps.content: Restore your saved files. After Windows has completed the installation process, you can insert your external hard drive or disc into the computer to restore your files back to the C drive.
